G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Massachusetts law imposes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in all residential lease agreements.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000 and Plaintiff resides within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Somerville District Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the property in question is located within this Court's jurisdiction.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: (establishing that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment can include non-physical interference).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment to cover serious interferences with the tenancy based on their natural and probable consequences, not limited to intentional, physical acts. It emphasizes that “quiet enjoyment” means freedom from serious interference with the character and value of the premises and allows recovery of “actual and consequential damages,” explicitly including emotional distress as a foreseeable consequence of the landlord’s interference. This confirms that breach of quiet enjoyment can encompass non-physical harms.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy… Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages… The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages… suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery.”

*Realty Co. v. Snow*, 245 Mass. 93 (1923.proposition: (explaining scope of a landlord’s legal responsibility under the covenant of quiet enjoyment).
*Realty Co. v. Snow*, 245 Mass. 93 (1923.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns bankruptcy, trust interests, and vested equitable remainders in an estate, not the obligations of a landlord under a covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not involve a landlord–tenant relationship, leases, or any discussion of the scope of a landlord’s legal responsibility for quiet enjoyment, so it cannot serve as authority for that proposition.
*Realty Co. v. Snow*, 245 Mass. 93 (1923.relevant_excerpt: The question to be determined is the nature of the interest of the bankrupt in the residue of the estate under clauses ninth and tenth of the agreement. … The true interpretation of this clause is that the bankrupt has a vested equitable remainder in the share of the fund to be paid upon his death. … The bankrupt’s vested interest in the income and in the equitable remainder passed to his trustee in bankruptcy.

*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.proposition: (describing areas of landlord liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14).
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.support_reasoning: The opinion contains a focused discussion of landlord liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the covenant of quiet enjoyment), explaining when a landlord’s omissions regarding security and third‑party criminal activity can amount to “serious interference” with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment and thus create liability. It distinguishes that statutory quiet enjoyment liability from other theories (habitability, nuisance, negligence), thereby describing the scope and limits of landlord liability under § 14 in this context.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.relevant_excerpt: “3. Covenant of quiet enjoyment. The plaintiffs argue that the judge erred in granting summary judgment in favor of the defendant on their claim that the defendant violated G. L. c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), the so-called ‘quiet enjoyment’ statute. … The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … [A] landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Doleh v. Carter*, 32 Mass. App. Ct. 911.proposition: (unreasonable noise can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment).
*Doleh v. Carter*, 32 Mass. App. Ct. 911.support_reasoning: Nothing in this opinion concerns landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or noise. The case is a criminal appeal about the sufficiency of fingerprint evidence in a breaking and entering and larceny prosecution. It therefore does not address, much less establish, any rule that unreasonable noise can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Doleh v. Carter*, 32 Mass. App. Ct. 911.relevant_excerpt: "Following a jury trial, the defendant was convicted of breaking and entering a building with the intent to commit a felony, and larceny. ... On appeal, the defendant claims that he was convicted solely on fingerprint evidence and argues that such evidence was insufficient to warrant the verdict."

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: (requiring landlord action upon notice of nuisance or interference).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses landlord liability under the quiet enjoyment statute and emphasizes that liability turns on the landlord’s notice and failure to act reasonably. The court states that to obtain relief under § 14 for lead poisoning, the tenant must show the landlord had notice or reason to know of the condition and failed to take appropriate corrective measures, which is consistent with a requirement of landlord action upon notice of an interfering condition or nuisance.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord… Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: (noise disturbances caused by landlord’s other tenants violate quiet enjoyment).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that landlords can breach the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, amounting to constructive eviction, where substantial noise and disturbances emanate from premises leased by the landlord to another tenant (here, a lounge), and the landlord has the right and ability to control or abate those disturbances. The court distinguishes the usual rule that landlords are not liable for one tenant’s annoyance of another and instead imposes liability because the noisy commercial use was created and controllable by the landlord. This directly supports the proposition that noise disturbances caused by a landlord’s other tenants can violate quiet enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Berman v. Holzer*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 14.proposition: (explaining treble damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for knowing violations).
*Berman v. Holzer*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 14.support_reasoning: The opinion in Berman v. Holzer concerns whether a negligence claim based on erroneous record keeping is barred by the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act’s exclusion for intentional torts like false imprisonment. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or treble damages for knowing violations. Thus it provides no authority on treble damages under that statute and does not support the claimed proposition.
*Berman v. Holzer*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 14.relevant_excerpt: "Pursuant to G. L. c. 258, § 10(c), governmental liability is not to attach to ‘any claim arising out of an intentional tort, including . . . false imprisonment, [or] false arrest.’ ... The plaintiff in this case has alleged negligent record keeping by county employees as the offending governmental activity leading to his improper arrest and imprisonment, rather that an intentional and unlawful confinement by the city police."
